NATIONAL CONGRESS OF PARENTS AND TEACHERS
700 North Rush Street, Chicago, Illinois 60611
NATIONAL EDUCATIONAL RADIO
Conference on Educational Radio as a National Resource
Racine, Wisconsin, September 26-28, 1966
Report of the National PTA Representative, Milton R. Litterst
The conference on Educational Radio as a National Resource, in Racine, Wis¬
consin, September 26-28, was sponsored by National Educational Radio, a di¬
vision of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters, in coopera¬
tion with the Johnson Foundation. It was attended by 70 key individuals
from government, industry, education, and the arts.
The purpose of the conference was to define and mobilize the unique resources
and potential of educational radio in order (l) to preserve and foster the
ideals of American education; (2) to provide the American people with infor¬
mation, instruction, and cultural enrichment in a manner and to a degree never
before attempted; and (3) to further the cause of international understanding.
E. G. Burrows, manager of Station WUOM, University of Michigan, and chairman
of the board of directors of National Educational Radio, was chairman of the
conference. The meeting place in Racine ttas "Wingspread,11 headquarters of
the Johnson Foundation, which was designed by Frank Lloyd Wright.
Leslie Paffrath, president of the Johnson Foundation, extended a warm wel¬
come to those in attendance and explained that "Wingspread" was more than a
unique building, it was in reality a center that had dedicated its resources
to developing a wide variety of cultural and educational programs devoted
to the exploration of all phases of the special, creative spirit of man.
Wingspread," he said, is an idea--a belief that man the individual is im¬
portant and that the potentialities inherent in his mind and spirit must be
encouraged to develop; and the building is intended to serve as a place where
men can exercise their creative and intellectual powers to their fullest.
Charles A. Siepmann, professor of communications at New York University and
author of many books and publications pertaining to educational radio broad¬
casting, was the keynote speaker. Several of his provocative statements
were as follows:
—Man has never communicated less significantly than he does today.
— Facts taken by themselves are an alibi for thinking, and they can become
the steam that obscures the mirror of truth.
Education must be played in a new key, since much of education, in the
broad sense, is outdated and antiquated.
—Education today must be provided from the cradle to the grave and must
become a way of life.
Education should involve all the agencies of the community, and it should
be of and for the community.
